Chapter 10: Generosity, the Chapter on Generosity in the Bodhisattva Ground

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas seeking anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi are fully endowed with the adornments of the six pÄramitÄs, namely, the pÄramitÄ of giving, the pÄramitÄ of morality, the pÄramitÄ of patience, the pÄramitÄ of diligence, the pÄramitÄ of meditation, and the pÄramitÄ of prajÃ±Ä.
What is called the bodhisattva's pÄramitÄ of giving?
There are nine kinds of bodhisattva giving:
First, natural giving;
Second, all giving;
Third, difficult giving;
Fourth, all self-giving;
Fifth, good person's giving;
Sixth, all practice giving;
Seventh, giving for elimination;
Eighth, giving for one's own benefit and the benefit of others;
Ninth, tranquil giving.

Generosity of nature refers to benefiting oneself, benefiting others, benefiting both oneself and others, giving rise to a good mind within, and the good actions of body, speech, and mind. Without attachment to wealth and possessions, this is called generosity.

When bodhisattvas practice generosity, they uphold precepts, diligently believe in the twelve divisions of the canon, believe in causes and effects, and according to the things sought by sentient beings, their minds are without stinginess, and with such actions of body, speech, and mind, they give away wealth and possessions.
These five things are precisely the five aggregates, and this is called generosity of nature.
What is generosity of all?
Generosity of all is of two kinds:
First, internal things;
Second, external things.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, for immeasurable eons, accept these aggregates for the sake of giving to sentient beings, and this is called internal things.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, for the sake of hungry ghosts who eat vomit, themselves ingest food, and then vomit and give it to them, and this is called internal things.
Apart from these two things, this is called external giving.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas giving away their bodies in acts of generosity have two things:
First, bodhisattvas do not have mastery;
Second, they belong to others.
If there are requests but they do not give, they cannot attain supreme perfect enlightenment. This is called bodhisattvas not having mastery.

As for belonging to others, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, for the sake of enlightenment, give their bodies to sentient beings, just as worldly people become servants for others for the sake of clothing and food.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not have mastery over their own bodies. All sentient beings, regarding the bodhisattvas' bodies, heads, eyes, marrow, brains, hands, and feet, take them as they wish and use them, and thus have mastery.
External giving has two things:
First, it is for the benefit of sentient beings;
Second, the mind is without greed or stinginess.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, regarding these internal and external [things], have giving and not giving.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas observe that if sentient beings receive their generosity and do not obtain benefit and happiness, then they do not practice generosity. If sentient beings receive their generosity and will definitely obtain benefit and happiness, then they practice generosity.

If bodhisattvas know that giving their bodies to sentient beings will cause them to suffer and hinder the practice of good dharmas, and if it is sought through unwholesome means, then they should not give.

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas see hundreds of thousands, millions, and billions of sentient beings who, due to unwholesome causes and conditions, are unable to obtain what they seek and lose their lives, they would never practice generosity for their sake.
Unwholesome means of seeking refers to killing, deceiving, stealing, and harming. This is called not giving.
There is also not giving. If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas know that their own bodies can benefit countless sentient beings, then they should not give if someone comes seeking. This is also called giving.
Why is it so?
Because of the pure mind.
If they know it is MÄra or MÄra's retinue, then they should not give.
If there are those who are confused and disturbed by demons and come seeking, one should also not give to them.
If there are those who are insane, deranged, or wish to cause trouble, one should also not give to such beggars.
This is called not giving internally.
As for not giving externally, fire, poison, knives, and alcohol can serve as evil causes and conditions for sentient beings. Bodhisattvas will never give these to people;
if they can benefit, then they give.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas will never make others do evil deeds. If they know that the recipient will definitely engage in evil deeds after receiving the gift, they will also not give to them.
This is also called giving.
Why is it so?
Because of the pure mind, even if the hands do not give, the mind has already let go.
Why is it so?

Because bodhisattvas definitely know that the person who receives the gift will definitely create immeasurable evil karma and fall into the three evil destinies after receiving it, therefore they do not give.
Although the bodhisattva knows that the recipient will be delighted to receive the gift, he knows that it will not prevent suffering in the three evil destinies, and therefore does not give it.

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva never instructs people to set up nets and traps for hunting, nor does he instruct people to serve the god PÄÅ›a. He himself does not kill sheep to sacrifice to the gods, nor does he instruct others to kill sheep to sacrifice to the gods. He does not give nets to those who come seeking, and he does not give all kinds of weapons to others.

If there are those in distress, poverty, and sorrow who wish to kill themselves, or seek knives and spears, he does not give them to them. He also does not instruct people to jump off high cliffs, drown in the depths, or burn themselves to death.
If there are sick people who need things that are prohibited by the doctor, he does not give them to them.
To those who are greedy for food, he does not give to those who have already eaten. This is called not giving.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not give away their parents, teachers, or elders. If they are rulers, they should not arbitrarily take others' wives and children to give to people, except for cities, towns, and countries.
If it is their own wife, children, servants, relatives, and clans, they should first comfort their minds with gentle words. If they are unwilling, they should not give them away.
Even if they are willing, they should never give them to enemies, evil people, rÄká¹£asas, evil ghosts, or caá¹‡á¸Älas.

Although they may give away cities, towns, countries, and villages to others, they should never give them to violent and evil people. They should also not privately give away the wealth of their parents, teachers, brothers, wives, children, servants, slaves, and so forth to others.
Bodhisattvas do not use wealth obtained through unrighteous means to practice giving.

When practicing giving, they should not be angry, beat, scold, or reprimand their own relatives, but should teach them with kind words to make them happy, saying, Such meritorious rewards are also your share.
When bodhisattvas give, their minds are impartial, not discriminating between those worthy of offerings and those unworthy, between enemies and friends, or between noble and lowly families.
They never regret giving what they have promised, never give less than what they have promised, and never give inferior things after promising superior ones.
They only give superior things after promising inferior ones, and more than promised after promising less.
When bodhisattvas give, they do so with a joyful mind, an unangry mind, and an unconfused mind. After giving, they never think of the recipient in terms of gratitude or repayment.
When practicing giving, they do not respect those of high status by offering with their own hands, nor do they treat those of low status with contempt.
If the recipient beats, scolds, or robs them, bodhisattvas never give rise to anger, but only blame their own afflictions and do not rebuke the person, and deeply feel compassion for them.
They never think:
Because of this giving, I will attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
This giving can also adorn enlightenment, not for the sake of seeking rewards.
All that is given is dedicated to supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Not practicing giving because of being taught by others, not practicing giving because of hearing of the rewards of giving.
As it is said in the sutra:
Giving food obtains strength, giving clothes obtains beauty, giving vehicles obtains happiness, giving lamps obtains good eyes, giving dwellings obtains whatever one desires.

Never hoping to obtain such rewards while practicing giving, only practicing giving out of compassion, practicing giving in order to break poverty, practicing giving in order to tame beings and attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Not giving is not giving.
Not giving means not giving leftovers to sages, not seeking and not giving to non-sages.
Do not give leftover food to parents, teachers, elders, or those with virtue. If the requester is suitable, then give to them.
Never give food mixed with vomit, pus, sweat, snot, feces, soil, or other impure substances to others. Do not give impure food to others.
When giving food, whether much or little, first speak and then give. Do not give without speaking.

Do not give food mixed with onions to those who do not eat onions. Do not give food mixed with meat to those who do not eat meat. Do not give food mixed with alcohol to those who do not drink alcohol. Do not give anything with the smell of alcohol. These are called impure things that should not be given as offerings.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas see those who come begging and give immediately when requested. They never give after coercing others.

They do not practice giving for the sake of heavenly pleasures, they do not practice giving for the sake of fame, they do not practice giving in order to receive rewards, they do not practice giving for the sake of becoming a wheel-turning sage king, they do not practice giving for the sake of becoming a demon king or Brahma king, they do not practice giving in order to be respected, revered, and offered to by kings, elders, or for the sake of villages, cities, or countries.
If they have little to give, they still give, let alone if they have much.
They do not practice giving in order to deceive, they do not practice giving in order to destroy others' retinues and form their own retinues, up to villages, cities, countries.

When a bodhisattva practices giving, they offer with their own hands to the most senior, up to novice monks, and to those who uphold the precepts and those who violate the precepts, without feeling tired.
When a bodhisattva practices giving, they never scold or disparage those who beg, and they do not practice giving out of arrogance.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas always give rise to a mind of abandonment towards all things, and the things they keep are always for the sake of sentient beings.
If one knows for certain that the bodhisattva has already given up [the object] and it belongs to oneself, then taking it as one's own portion is not a transgression.

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas see a beggar, their minds are filled with joy, like a seriously ill person seeing a great doctor. They allow them to take whatever they need as they please, and are joyful during the three times - before giving, while giving, and after giving. When bodhisattvas give, they always give rise to this thought.
Even if there are poor and rich people who come to beg, they should think to themselves:
If I have many things, I should give equally to all. If I have few things, I should first save those who are poor and suffering.
Making this vow is the cause for supreme, perfect enlightenment.
There are three kinds of stinginess, namely, lower, middling, and upper.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas first destroy the lower stinginess, because by destroying the lower stinginess they are able to destroy the middling and upper two kinds of stinginess. Having themselves destroyed stinginess, they also expound the Dharma of destroying stinginess for sentient beings. Because of expounding the Dharma, they benefit sentient beings.
Furthermore, a bodhisattva forcefully gives things to those who do not seek them. If one has no wealth, one should seek it through skillful means and give it away.
If one has no material giving, one should practice giving the Dharma and teach sentient beings:
Why do you not practice giving now?
If the person in front follows and practices giving, one should deeply rejoice and use one's physical strength to assist and replace their efforts.
Moreover, those without wealth should use wisdom to reveal good and evil for all sentient beings.

Furthermore, a bodhisattva does not give the true canon to those with wrong views, nor does one sell sÅ«tras and vinaya for the sake of livelihood. If one reads and recites them, one should give them away. If one is stingy and does not give, it is called stinginess with the Dharma.
If one is able to expound the Dharma but does not do so for others, it is also called stinginess with the Dharma.
If I am unable to give the Dharma to others, how can I destroy the afflictions of sentient beings?
A bodhisattva never says:
I now have no wealth and cannot practice giving.
They also do not become angry or upset themselves.
With skillful means, they comfort those who seek:
I do not have it now, so I cannot fulfill your intention.
Why is it so?
Because when I first gave rise to the mind of enlightenment, I said I would give to all sentient beings.

Furthermore, when bodhisattvas hear that someone has come to seek, they immediately go out to receive them and offer them a seat. After meeting, they first speak with a friendly attitude and ask about their well-being with gentle words, and provide them with whatever they need.
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, when first giving rise to the mind of enlightenment, say:
All the possessions I have now, I will give to the buddhas, bodhisattvas, and sentient beings in the ten directions.
It is like a disciple offering their robes and alms bowl to their teacher. Even if the teacher does not accept them, this disciple still obtains immeasurable merit.

Bodhisattvas are also like this. All the things they possess they offer to the buddhas and bodhisattvas. Although the buddhas and bodhisattvas do not accept them, they also cause the givers to obtain immeasurable blessings, which always follow the bodhisattvas like the Ganges sands.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas view their own wealth as entrusted by the buddhas and bodhisattvas of the ten directions. They know that the buddhas and bodhisattvas have no stinginess or greed towards this wealth, and therefore the bodhisattvas freely give to sentient beings according to their wishes.
They also deeply contemplate those who should not be given to and should be admonished:
'Such wealth is truly not mine, but belongs to the buddhas and bodhisattvas.'
With gentle words they enlighten the seekers, not causing them to become angry or resentful.
Therefore, bodhisattvas accomplish and perfect the two kinds of giving: the giving of wealth and the giving of the Dharma.

Having perfected the two kinds of giving, they know the nature, know the causes, know the effects, and know the distinctions.ğŸ”½If bodhisattvas give to their enemies, it is because of the cause of kindness.
If they give to those who are suffering, it is because of the cause of compassion.
If one gives to the virtuous, it is due to the cause of joy.
If one gives to relatives, siblings, and servants, it is due to the cause of letting go.
This is called the giving of wisdom by the bodhisattva.
Furthermore, the bodhisattva knows the mind of stinginess in giving.
The mind of stinginess in giving is of four kinds:
First, because one has not been accustomed to giving for immeasurable lives;
Second, because one has few possessions;
Third, because one is attached to fine things;
Fourth, because one does not seek good karmic rewards in future lives.

If the bodhisattva mahÄsattva sees a beggar who has wealth and possessions but does not immediately give rise to the mind of giving, this is the bodhisattva's mind of stinginess in giving that has not been accustomed to giving for immeasurable lives.
At that time, the bodhisattva should use the power of wisdom to contemplate:
'Because I have not been accustomed to giving for immeasurable lives in the past, I do not immediately give rise to the mind of giving.
I now have many possessions and there are those who seek them. If I do not give them away, in future lives I will further increase my stingy mind and will never follow or cultivate a mind of giving.'
Furthermore, the bodhisattva sees that because of having few possessions, he does not immediately give rise to a mind of giving. The bodhisattva should further contemplate with the power of wisdom:

'Because of immeasurable evil karmic conditions, for immeasurable lifetimes my body belonged to others, and I experienced great suffering, hunger, thirst, cold, and heat. I was unable to benefit immeasurable sentient beings. Because of these karmic conditions, my body has few possessions.
If I do not give now, I will further increase poverty and suffering in future lives.
If I now give this small amount to others, although I will be poor and suffering, I will not end up in the suffering of the three evil paths.'
Having contemplated in this way, he is able to destroy the stingy mind towards small possessions.

Furthermore, when a bodhisattva sees a petitioner and a greedy mind arises towards a cherished object, not immediately giving rise to the thought of giving, the bodhisattva should then use wisdom to contemplate:
'I have the notion of permanence towards the impermanent, and the notion of mine towards what is not mine.
If I do not give, then I will increase attachment, which is my delusion.'
Therefore, the bodhisattva is able to destroy the greedy mind towards cherished objects.
Furthermore, when the bodhisattva does not practice giving in order to seek rewards, the bodhisattva should then contemplate and say:
'All dharmas are impermanent and unstable. If they were permanent and stable, then giving would not be necessary.
Why is this?
Because there would be no cause and effect.
Since they are impermanent, there is cause and effect.
If I do not give now, how will I attain the fruit of the path of enlightenment?'
Therefore, the bodhisattva is able to destroy the mind that does not seek rewards and practice generous giving.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas know the four inverted [views], that dharmas have no fixed [nature] and no characteristic of permanence, and therefore they are able to destroy the four hateful and evil minds.
Furthermore, the bodhisattva is tranquil within his body and contemplates with his mind, always thinking like this:
'If I have wealth, I will use it to make offerings to the buddhas, bodhisattvas, and the Dharma and Saá¹…gha.'
This is called the bodhisattva's wisdom giving.
Having wealth or not having wealth, always thinking like this with a focused mind, the same is true for giving the Dharma. This is called giving everything.
How is it that the bodhisattva gives what is difficult to give?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, if they have little possessions, always use them to give generously. This is called giving what is difficult to give.

The things that the mind loves and is attached to, which are obtained through diligent seeking for immeasurable lifetimes, and which are obtained through great skillful means and hard work, using such things to give generously to others, this is called giving what is difficult to give.
What is giving everything oneself?
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas themselves practice giving, or if they teach their parents, siblings, spouse, children, relatives, and servants to practice giving, this is called giving by oneself.
What is giving by good people?
If good men give with a good mind, a faithful mind, a sincere mind, with their own hands, at the right time, and with wealth obtained lawfully, this is called giving by good people.
What is giving practiced by all bodhisattvas?
Because they do not seek rewards, it is called giving practiced by all.
Because they always give, it is called giving practiced by all.
Because they give to fields of merit, it is called giving practiced by all.
Because they give without discriminating between fields of merit and non-fields of merit, it is called giving practiced by all.
Because they do not discriminate between timely and untimely, it is called giving practiced by all.
Because they do not discriminate between wealth that can be given and wealth that cannot be given, it is called giving practiced by all.
What is giving for the sake of eliminating [suffering] by bodhisattvas?

If there are sentient beings suffering from hunger and thirst, in order to eliminate this, one practices giving. Giving clothes to the cold, giving vehicles to those seeking vehicles, giving necklaces to those seeking necklaces, fragrant ointments, powdered incense, various flowers, lamps, dwellings, bedding, and medicine for the sick are also like this. This is called giving in order to eliminate.
What is giving for one's own benefit and the benefit of others?
If a bodhisattva mahÄsattva gives wealth and Dharma to others, he can create two kinds of happiness for himself and sentient beings in the two worlds.
Always giving sentient beings the happiness of fearlessness, namely saving from the dangers of tigers, wolves, lions, water, fire, kings, enemies, and thieves, this is called giving fearlessness.
As for the Dharma giving of bodhisattva mahÄsattvas, whatever is said is originally without error. This is called Dharma giving.
Skillfully teaching and admonishing all sentient beings is called pure Dharma giving.
The giving of wealth benefits the present, while practicing Dharma giving benefits the present and future lives.
There is also material giving, which may cause suffering for sentient beings in the present world;
The giving of Dharma is not like this, as it can bring about happiness for oneself and others in the present and future worlds.
Material giving is impure, while the giving of Dharma is pure.
Those who practice material giving are not called boundless, while the giving of the Dharma is called boundless giving.
Material giving is easy to obtain, while the giving of the Dharma is difficult to encounter.
This is called the giving that benefits oneself and others.
What is meant by the giving of tranquility?
The giving of tranquility has ten aspects.
What are the ten?
First, giving without obstruction;
Second, giving without error;
Third, giving that is not for adornment;
Fourth, giving without arrogance;
Fifth, giving with an unattached mind;
Sixth, giving without shame;
Seventh, giving without sorrow;
Eighth, giving without a sullen face;ğŸ”½Ninth, giving without seeking gratitude in return;
Tenth, giving without seeking karmic rewards. Giving without obstruction means:

When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice giving, they are not obstructed by all the worldly affairs, and although they know the mind of the seeker is without delay, they are able to quickly let go and satisfy their requests. This is called unobstructed giving.
Unmistaken giving means that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas never think:
Giving has no karmic retribution, no good or bad consequences.
They also do not think:
Giving while killing, like what Vá¹›á¹£alÄ« said, obtains good karmic consequences.
Because of not being attached to the causes and conditions of giving, one obtains the fruits of worldly happiness and anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi. This is called unmistaken giving.
Non-adornment giving means that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas never accumulate things to make good adornments and practice giving. They give as they obtain them, never hoarding.
Why is this?
Because bodhisattvas deeply know that the two dharmas of wealth and life are impermanent and difficult to preserve.
If there are those who come seeking, upon encountering them one immediately gives, never saying:
'Wait for me to adorn myself and then I will give.'
Why is this?
Adorned giving is not called the adornment of anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
If a bodhisattva waits to give while adorned, then it causes sentient beings to greatly suffer.
This is called non-adorned giving.

Giving without a lofty mind means that when a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva sees a petitioner, they give rise to a humble mind and do not praise themselves, saying, I am a donor. They do not seek to repay kindness, and do not give in order to surpass others in the fame of their practice of giving. This is called giving without a lofty mind.
Giving with an unattached mind means that a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva does not attach importance to fame.

Bodhisattvas skillfully observe that fame is like empty space, like the wind, like the fibers in lotus roots. If one seeks fame in giving, then one will not attain supreme perfect enlightenment. Therefore, bodhisattvas seek supreme perfect enlightenment without seeking fame. This is called giving with an unattached mind.
Giving without shame means that when practicing giving, one joyfully gives at the three times. This is called giving without shame.
Giving without sorrow means that when bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas give their most treasured possessions, they have no regrets. Therefore, they are without sorrow. This is called giving without sorrow.

Giving without a frowning face means that bodhisattvas universally observe all sentient beings, their minds are impartial, and they are happy to see everyone. This is called giving without a frowning face.

Giving without seeking repayment of kindness means that out of compassion, cultivating kindness, bestowing peace and happiness, and not seeking recompense, this is called giving without seeking repayment of kindness.

Giving without seeking rewards means when bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas practice giving, they do not seek the body of a wheel-turning sage king, the thirty-three heavens, the heavens of MÄra, BrahmÄ, or the freedom of wealth.
Why is it so?
Because bodhisattvas deeply contemplate conditioned phenomena as being like plantain trees, therefore when giving, they do not seek rewards. This is called giving without seeking rewards.
These ten things can enable bodhisattvas to fully accomplish the perfection of giving and attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Chapter 11: The Chapter on Morality, from the Bodhisattva Ground, What is called the morality of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas?
Morality has nine kinds:
First, inherent morality;
Second, all morality;
Third, difficult morality;
Fourth, all self-morality;
Fifth, good person's morality;
Sixth, all practice morality;
Seventh, eliminating morality;
Eighth, morality for benefiting oneself and others;
Ninth, the precept of tranquility.
As for the precept of self-nature, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who possess the precept of self-nature have four merits:
First, with a pure mind, they receive it from others;

Second, if their minds are impure and they violate the precepts they have received, they should sincerely repent with a sense of shame. After repenting, they single-mindedly vow not to commit offenses again.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who receive precepts from others give rise to a sense of shame and remorse. Because their minds are ashamed and remorseful, they protect and uphold the precepts without violating them.
If their minds are impure and they violate the precepts they have received, because they are ashamed and remorseful, they do not dare to conceal their transgressions even for a single night.

If bodhisattvas violate the precepts and spend a night [without repenting], if they wish to repent, they should not simply repent as if committing a single offense, but should repent as if committing innumerable offenses in each thought.
Why is this?
If those who commit many offenses repent as if committing a single offense, it is not called repentance, and the receiver commits an offense.
When bodhisattvas receive and uphold the precepts from others, there are four things:
First, a sense of shame;
Second, upholding with utmost sincerity, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas uphold the precepts with utmost sincerity, never giving rise to thoughts of violating them;
Third, after accepting them, they protect and uphold them with a one-pointed mind;
Fourth, they accept and uphold them with a pure mind.
Bodhisattvas who are endowed with the four meritorious virtues of the precepts can accomplish four things.
What are the four?
First, not committing offenses;
Second, if an offense is committed, immediately repenting;
Third, giving rise to a sense of shame and remorse;
Fourth, not giving rise to regret.
This is called the precepts of inherent virtue.

Bodhisattvas with the precepts of inherent virtue are called those with true precepts, precepts that benefit both self and others, precepts that benefit sentient beings, precepts that benefit sentient beings in accordance with principle, precepts that increase the number of humans and gods, and precepts of immeasurable merit.
Bodhisattvas who accomplish such precepts give rise to a compassionate mind and are then able to teach and transform immeasurable sentient beings.

If bodhisattvas do not repent of the afflictions that are like guests and dust, they should always praise others for upholding the precepts and reprimand those who violate the precepts, speaking of the faults incurred by those who violate the precepts.
If one is able to do this, although it is called violating the precepts, the faults are slight, and one will also be able to ultimately attain supreme perfect enlightenment.
This is called the intrinsic nature of precepts.
As for all precepts, those upheld by laypeople and renunciants are called all precepts.
There are three kinds of precepts for laypeople and renunciants:
first, precepts;
second, precepts for receiving wholesome dharmas;
third, precepts practiced for the sake of benefiting sentient beings.
What are called precepts?
They refer to the precepts of the seven assemblies:
bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, Å›iká¹£aá¹‡Ä-maá¹‡á¸ikas, Å›rÄmaá¹‡eras, Å›rÄmaá¹‡erÄ«s, upÄsakas, and upÄsikÄs.
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas wish to uphold the bodhisattva precepts, they should first purify their minds and receive the seven kinds of precepts.
The seven kinds of precepts are precisely the pure mind that leads to the bodhisattva precepts.
Just as when worldly people wish to invite the king, they must first keep their dwelling clean.
These seven kinds of precepts are both for the ordained and the laity.
The bodhisattva precepts are also like this, both for the ordained and the laity. This is called the precepts.
What is called receiving the precepts of wholesome dharmas?

As for the precepts of wholesome dharmas, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, apart from the seven kinds of precepts, cultivate the ten wholesome dharmas of body, speech, and mind for the sake of bodhi. This is called receiving the precepts of wholesome dharmas.

As for body, speech, and mind, if bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abide in the stage of precepts, they should read, recite, copy, explain, contemplate, and cultivate Å›amatha and vipaÅ›yanÄ. They should respectfully make offerings, revere and praise their teachers, preceptors, elders, and those with virtue. From time to time they should provide for them, attend to them, and run errands for them. If they are sick or old, or exhausted from traveling, they should carry their robes and alms bowls for them. If they see someone expounding the Dharma or chanting sÅ«tras, they should praise them as excellent. If they see those who uphold the precepts, they should protect them to the utmost and praise the precepts. They should wish that all sentient beings will uphold pure precepts.
If they see those who violate the precepts, they should deeply feel compassion for them, reprimand them with kind words, and teach them to repent.
All the wholesome actions they perform with their body, speech, and mind, they should vow to dedicate towards anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.

Whenever there is physical, verbal, or mental strength, one diligently makes offerings to the Three Jewels with a sincere mind, diligently cultivates vigor in order to increase wholesome dharmas, and cultivates non-negligence in order to attain all wholesome dharmas.
